Document.H4: 8.08.03 Using non-Canadian service agents for the exploitation of productions on videograms (DVDs / Blu-rays) or on online platforms
Document.P: The use of a non-Canadian service agent to prepare productions for exploitation in Canada during the two-year period will not be considered a distribution by a non-Canadian if their services are provided under the control of a Canadian distributor, and are limited to the functions set out below:

LI.LBody: For the purpose of videograms (DVDs or Blu-rays), these services may include:
the procurement and manufacturing of videograms and their packaging;
the storage of the videograms
order entry and order processing through computer and inventory control systems;
the shipping of the videograms to customary sales and retail outlets; and
accounting to the distributor for all videogram sales to customers.

For the purpose of preparing files for digital download or online streaming platforms, these services should be restricted to technical functions including the reformatting, encoding or uploading of files for exploitation on these platforms. This includes industry-standard commercial arrangements made for this purpose with entities commonly known as “aggregators.”

Document.P: A Canadian distributor may enter into an agreement with a non-Canadian service agent for the provision of these services in Canada provided that, within the two-year period following completion of the production:

LI.LBody: There is a contract between the Canadian production company and the Canadian distributor to distribute the production in Canada;
Canadian distribution rights are retained at all times by a Canadian-owned and -controlled corporation;
The Canadian distributor remains at all times responsible for performing the customary functions of a distributor, as outlined above in section 8.04.02 .

Document.P: The agreement with the non-Canadian service agent must be made for a standard service fee.

The production company will also be asked to provide CAVCO with any agreement between the Canadian distributor and the non-Canadian service agent and/or demonstrate that the production has been made available.

Other than where a production is a treaty coproduction, the applicant must demonstrate that an acceptable share of revenues from the exploitation of the production in non-Canadian markets is retained by:

LI.LBody: a qualified corporation that owns or owned an interest in the production,
a prescribed taxable Canadian corporation related to the qualified corporation, or
any combination of (a) and (b).

Document.P: To meet the acceptable revenues requirement, the production company (or a related prescribed taxable Canadian corporation) must retain at least 25% of the net profits from the exploitation of the production in non-Canadian markets. In determining whether this requirement has been met, CAVCO will consider a number of relevant factors, including, among other things:

LI.LBody: whether distribution fees and expenses are contracted at rates consistent with established industry standards;
where a broadcasting entity is also granted distribution rights, whether the allocation of funds between the broadcast licence and the distribution licence is commercially reasonable; and
whether the profit participation in any non-Canadian territory granted by the producer to investors is in keeping with established industry standards.

Document.P: Note that the production company must also retain an acceptable share of revenues in Canada.

Format programs are based on popular concepts or formats initially produced and exploited in another territory. Format programs produced in Canada by a Canadian production company, under a licence issued by the non-Canadian owner of the underlying rights, are eligible for the CPTC. 28
28 While section 8.10 focuses on format productions created outside Canada, the same principles will apply where rights to a Canadian-originated format production are licensed to a different territory within Canada.
Document.H4: 8.10.02 Clarifications regarding the eligibility of format productions

LI.LBody: Exploitation rights can be restricted to Canada only.

Document.P: The terms of the format license agreement can restrict the exploitation of a format program to the Canadian territory only, or to a specific territory in Canada (one province, for example).

LI.LBody: The length of the exploitation term granted to the Canadian production company cannot be restricted to less than 25 years.

Document.P: The format licence agreement cannot limit the length of time during which the production company can exploit the production in territories granted to it under the terms of the agreement. For example, the format owner cannot indicate that the right to
exploitation in Canada is limited to a period of 5 years. See also section 8.01.02 .

LI.LBody: The Canadian production company must have control over the exploitation rights of its production in any other territories.

Document.P: If the production is being exploited in additional territories outside Canada, the Canadian production company must control the initial licensing of commercial exploitation rights in these territories. In other words, an agreement cannot indicate that the format rights holder has chosen to retain these foreign exploitation rights as part of the terms of the original licensing of rights.

LI.LBody: The production must continue to meet all the usual requirements for CPTC eligibility.

Document.P: A format program must continue to meet all CPTC requirements, including with respect to copyright ownership, production control and the retaining of an acceptable share of revenues from any exploitation of the production in non-Canadian territories.
